title: cautiously safely kids back to school
story: THE question of when and how we re-open our schools is one of the key issues the nation will face when it steps carefully away from this Covid- lockdown.Based on the evidence, I believe that re-opening schools should be considered early in the exit strategy because it appears they play a relatively small role in transmissions.We tend to see children as excellent spreaders of bugs, and therefore ­closing schools seems to make sense.Yet research published earlier this week shows that this isn’t necessarily true for the Covid- virus.Almost everything we know about closing schools to stop disease outbreaks comes from influenza.Flu is a very dferent virus to coronavirus, and children drive much of influenza’s transmission.Coronavirus is less likely to affect children and young people.They rarely get very sick, and they mostly get very mild symptoms or show no ­symptoms at all.During the  epidemic caused by Sars — a cousin of Covid- — the data showed that schools and schoolchildren played no role in transmitting the virus.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealClosing schools harms our children in many ways.Yes, many of them are getting some online teaching  —  my -year-old had brilliant support from his school before the holidays.But we know that some schools are offering much less, and I worry that it is particularly the poorest children who are ­missing out.Children also benefit from school through contact with friends and adults outside their family.Plus there is support for mental health and even in the food that they might not get at home.School closures also force children together with parents at home for weeks on end.This can be a source of great bonding, but we know that, particularly for teens, being cut off from peer groups and other adults is not good for their development or mental health.The issue of forcing key worker parents to stay home has been largely solved during the pandemic by keeping some schools open just for their ­children.But for parents who are not key workers, being forced to look after ­children for weeks at home can prevent them earning an income.Closing schools has in the past been shown to increase social contacts between children outside school, and between children and adults looking after them, particularly grandparents, who are most vulnerable to this virus.Currently, those over  should be self- isolating away from children.But there are many grandparents who are under .Andschools stay closed while we allow adults to exit lockdown first, we risk an increase in contact between children and grandparents.One of the problems is that we tend to think of schools as being entirely closed or open.Our research showed that there are a range of potential options.It would mean a partial or staged re-opening with social distancing built in.The point of social distancing for schools is to reduce the number of children in contact at any one time.Ensuring that dferent school years don’t meet would be a useful start.So have half the school attend in the morning and half in the afternoon, close the playgrounds and stagger year-group start, end and break times so that ­dferent years never meet.Then ensure that dferent classes don’t meet.This could mean staggering start times by class or alternating the ways that classes enter and leave school, and ­keeping students in form classes for all their lessons.Schools could also look at how feasible social distancing is within classes.True, most British classrooms could not fit a metre between desks.However,only half of the school is attending at any one time, classes could spread out across more than one classroom.We also need very clear rules on when not to come to school with any ­symptoms, and the need for self-isolation at homeothers in the family had been ill will be required.Teachers need to be protected, as we protect those who ­continue to drive buses, man shopping centres and work in our health ­system.And teachers should be early in the queue for testing.This may all sound too dficult.However, we owe it to our ­children to examine all of these options.It could be done more easilywe had sufficient testing to know which children or teachers had had Covid-.But we may need to proceed ­without that, given what we are currently told about antibody-testing timescales.As mentioned, our schools are already ­partially open — for the children of key workers and vulnerable children.Let’s gradually increase that “partially” in a way that’s guided by science.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: families favourite pastimes coronavirus lockdown
story: A GRAN whose once-in-a-letime safari trip was ruined by coronavirus has instead created a ft elephant in the garden to ride on.Gail Blackwell, , had been planning a trip to Kenya with a friend when the Covid- pandemic struck.Luckily her green-fingered husband Eric, , was able to trim a bush in their garden to recreate Gail’s favourite animal - the African elephant.The couple, of Taunton, Somerset, have nicknamed the leafy green mammal ‘Nellie’ and even attached tusks which Eric picked up in an abattoir.Gail told The Sun: “I was so looking forward to going to Kenya but coronavirus has shut everything down so it seems the only animals I might see this year will be at Longleat.“I absolutely adore animals, elephants and giraffes are my favourite, I would love to see them in the wild and a trip to Kenya would have been a once-in-a-letime opportunity.”Part-time receptionist Gail and Eric, who is disabled and unable to leave their home, have been stuck indoors like millions of others during the coronavirus crisis.But their garden project has given the pair hours of entertainment.Gail added: “We have been coping with the virus and dreaming about the holidays.“Last year I was lucky enough to go away to Dubai, Turkey and I went on a Mediterranean cruise but this year I wanted to go a bit further, a safari has always been my dream but for the moment Nellie will have to do.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mum preparing dinner found smiley face inside pepper

Aides say Boris is in good spirits and and is now back walking as his overall condition improves.A source told the Sun : “It’s been a very, very worrying time for Carrie.She has been urging Boris to get well for their unborn child.” The engaged couple have not seen each other for over a month over concerns for Carrie who is isolating while pregnant. Boris, , has used the time off to watch his favourite movies - including Withnail and I and JRR Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings trilogy - as he recuperates in hospital. He is also reported to have finally watched Love Actually. The PM has also expressed his deep gratitude to staff at St. Thomasapos who he believes likely saved his le - but it remains unclear when he will be able toto action. A No  spokeswoman added: “He has spoken to his doctors and thanks the whole clinical team for the incredible care he has received. “His thoughts are with those affected by this terrible disease.”  After three days in intensive care, Mr Johnson was moved out onto a ward last night shortly before the pm aposClap for Carersapos. Today his spokesman said: The Prime Minister is back on a ward and continuing his recovery which is at an early stage. He continues to be in very good spirits.The Sun reported he phoned his heavily pregnant fiancee Carrie Symonds as soon as doctors handed him back his phones.Mr Johnsonaposs father Stanley today said his son almost took one for the team and his illness should highlight how anyone can be laid low by Covid-.Downing Street has not commented on when the PM might be discharged from hospital, saying it will be a decision for his doctors. Mr Johnson Senior has suggested the PM - who experts say could taken weeks to recover full health - should recuperate at his grace-and-favour country retreat Chequers. story: NewsCoronavirus: Footballers urged to support first aiders to ensure Premier League EXCLUSIVE St John Ambulance provides all of the Premier Leagues volunteer first aiders - but CEO Martin Houghton-Brown says the charity needs £m on top of the governments charity bailout in order to bounce backShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  APR News " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Footballers and clubs should team up to support their volunteer first-aiders who are now working on the coronavirus front lines, the boss of St John Ambulance has said.St John provides almost all first aiders to Premier League matches - and the charity say it would be “impossible” to restart professional football unless they can bounce back after the crisis.On Tuesday, Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £m package of support for charities struggling after fundraising events and charity shops were forced to close.Voluntary sector bosses say the total shortfall in income over the next  weeks will be more than £ billion. And St John CEO Martin Houghton-Brown told the Mirror it will need £ million in donations on top of their share of the government cashit is to rebuild after the crisis. He said: The reality is that eventhey meet that shortfall, that still assumes Iaposm going to raise £m from the public to ensure that St John can do everything it needs to, not just now but into the future. The entire St John organisation is now focused on tackling the Covid- pandemic, supporting NHS hospitals with volunteers and providing ambulance services. Mr Houghton-Brown said as many as  volunteers could be deployed to the NHS Nightingale hospital in London once it is fully operational. Askedthe charity would be able to continue providing first-aiders to football matches after the pandemic, Mr Houghton Brown said: It is my hope. But he added: I think that the football community should recognise that their football first-aiders are now fighting Covid.” Premier League clubs have already come under fire during the crisis for continuing to pay players eye-watering sums, while relying on the government furlough scheme to pay other staff. He added: “Wouldnapost it be wonderfulwe could build an alliance with football clubs and players to support those volunteers who have saved us on the front line ”  Mr Houghton-Brown said the scale of the enormous NHS Nightingale hospital set up at the Excel Centre in London was similar to the cavernous Terminal  at Heathrow Airport. “Itaposs that scale,” he said. “Itaposs huge. Itaposs just an extraordinary space where something incredibly professional, incredibly clinically sound has been built.”

story: NewsDozens of House of Lords staff on zero-hour contracts despite calls to ban themEXCLUSIVE: The Lords has  workers on iable hours contracts with no weekly minimum, more than in , while peers are paid £ for each day they turn upShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  APR NewsThe Lords has  workers on iable hours contracts with no weekly minimum " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDozens of House of Lords staff are on zero-hour contracts despite attempts to ban the deals. Some  workers have no guaranteed weekly minimum hours - while peers can claim £ for each day they turn up. The number of these iable hours contracts has risen from  since . SNP MP Chris Stephens, who has led a backbench Bill aiming to ban zero-hour contracts, told the Mirror: “There’s no excuse for anybody to be in a zero hour contract in parliament or not.“There shouldn’t be any need at all for anything other than guaranteed hours contracts.” Almost a million workers in the UK are on zero-hour contracts.  The number in the Lords was disclosed following a Freedom of Information request by the Mirror. As of February ,  catering and retail staff and  Hansard reporters, who record debates in the Lords chamber, were on “iable hours contracts”. Officials said this meant they have no minimum weekly hours, though when they do work a sht, they are booked for a guaranteed minimum number of hours for that day. Asked the same question, the House of Commons said it had no directly-employed zero-hours staff - though authorities could not comment on any agency staff or contractors. A Lords spokesman defended the deals, saying the workers were used instead of casual staff and receive pension, holiday, sick pay and at least the London Living Wage of £. an hour. They can also turn down shts without the threat of losing further work in future.  But Mr Stephens said: “People need to organise their lives. They will have transport costs, childcare costs. “We want to see seven days’ notice for people to come in andit changes within those seven days they should get double time.”Lords officials have pledged the zero-hour workers will continue to be paid during the coronavirus pandemic.They will receive their average weekly earnings over the four weeks to March , as long as they have worked a sht since September.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs another Lent ends, I’ve finally begun to realise what it meant to spend  days in the wilderness. OK, I’ve only had three weeks of it and, unlike Jesus, I’ve been able to eat and drink, although Satan is tempting me every afternoon to sup unholy spirits. The gospels don’t say exactly what He did to kill time in lockdown in the Judean desert, but I’m guessing he pledged to do a lot of things, and failed. That’s my story. I told myself I’d re-discover books, but whenever I got a few pages into one I’d hear an alert on my phone, look away, spend half an hour scrolling, and realise all literature is doomedit exceeds  characters. I tried to learn how to cook something new to add to the one dish a week I make, but my paella stuck to the pan and I lashed it into the bin when one of the kids laughed and askedit was called a paella crap. I grew a beard, which I thought made me look a bit like Al Pacino in Serpico, only for my we to tell me I looked like Jon Pertwee in Worzel Gummidge. I decided to put a coat of nish on the rotting garden furniture but the three paint brushes I had were glued together with old paint, and when I drove to BQ, they turned me away because I hadn’t worked out how to click and collect from them. I never will. So I turned to Netflix, hoping to get hooked on a new American drama or documentary series and got so bored I ended up scouring US news channels to find a Donald Trump press conference for some mental stimulation.  And then a week ago I did something that finally beat the lockdown blues. I dug out my old DVD box sets and started to re-watch comedy classics. I devoured The Office, delighting again at Ricky Gervais’s glorious anti-PC creation David Brent. I stuck on Fawlty Towers and remembered how funny John Cleese used to be before he became a real-le whining malcontent. Watching the greatest political satire ever, The Thick Of It, left me marvelling at the master of the four-lettered insult Malcolm Tucker.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGiving birth is dficult at the best of times - and during a global pandemic is sure to cause anxiety for many mums-to-be. Thankfully, NHS staff have been at hand to battle the disease and letting midwives get on with the job of delivering babies. The world might seem a dark place at the moment, but these amazing babies would put a smile on anyone’s face… Jodie Mills and Rosie “From the moment we were put in lockdown, I was anxious about going into hospital and giving birth in the current situation,” says Jodie. “It was my second child and when my contractions started at am on April , my sister drove over to look after our son, Reggie,  months, and my husband, David, , drove me to Darlington Memorial Hospital. “My contractions were coming thick and fast.”  The -year-old from Catterick Garrison, North Yorks, added: “We quickly made our way up to the maternity ward on the sixth floor. However, the baby didn’t want to wait – she was halfway out when we were in the lt! “All the staff had gloves on and I managed to hold her in until we got to the double doors of the maternity ward. My husband was frantically buzzing the bell for assistance before a midwe appeared. “She ran out and quickly took off her cardigan and delivered our baby in the corridor. “Our daughter, Rosie, was born at :am. She weighed lb oz. I was very nervous because of the pandemic but the care we received at both the labour and maternity ward was second to none, they were professional, friendly and reassured you. “My husband was allowed in the labour ward, but was only allowed to stay a short while. We had to stay  hours to be monitored and then partners weren’t allowed in to collect us, so a nurse helped walk me down to the car. “I can’t thank all the staff enough – especially the midwe that took her cardigan off to catch Rosie!” Laura Gillham and baby Rudy “My labour was really quite good considering everything that is going on,” says Laura, .  “I gave birth to my first child at Darlington Memorial Hospital and the staff and midwives were amazing! “At first I had planned on having two birthing partners, my boyfriend Brad, , and my mam, Sharon. But two weeks before my due date I found out that because of the pandemic the rules had been changed so that I could only have one birthing partner. Learning that my mam couldn’t be there was slightly upsetting but understandable. “On April , I was in labour and Brad was allowed with me. After seven hours our son, Rudy, was born at :pm, weighing lb. “Brad was with me the whole time and didn’t miss a thing, he was even allowed to cut the cord. The whole experience was amazing!” Laura, from Darlington, Co Durham, added: “Mam hasn’t got to meet him yet, only through the window. She can’t wait to meet him in person for a proper cuddle!” Zoe Green and Joss “I gave birth to my seventh baby on March . I’d already been self-isolating for two weeks due to being pregnant and having bad asthma,” explains Zoe.  “When I started having contractions I went to Colchester General Hospital. “But then the contractions stopped. “I was about to be sent home when a matron came on the ward to speak to everyone and explained that from that point onwards the pandemic meant that no visitors would be allowed on the wards any more and partners would only be allowed at the birth.” The -year-old from Colchester, Essex, added: “I went home feeling a bit sad but on a mission to get my labour going before the hospital got any worse.  “The next day I did a YouTube inducing-labour exercise video, bounced on my ball every chance I got, went for a long walk and then had pineapple and to finish the day, ordered myself a hot curry and had a lavender bath... and then went to bed with my fingers crossed. I got my wish as I heard my waters pop in my sleep at .am. “I was booked in for an elective C-section and they didn’t want me going into full-blown labour. “I grabbed my bag and notes, and headed to the hospital where my baby’s dad, Dan, met me. “There was also another lady in the other room for the exact same thing so the poor midwives were going from room to room washing their hands coming in and when they left. “Our baby boy, Joss Henry Craig Green, was born at :am weighing lb oz. “All the staff we met were absolutely amazing and so lovely and reassuring.”  Angela Ahmed and Twins Trent and Tallulah “I was  weeks pregnant with twins and already had two other sons, Jamal, , and Kia, , when on March  I started suffering with cramps,” says Angela,  from Bromsgrove. “I went to Royal Worcester Hospital and I expected to be sent home with paracetamol, instead I was  centimetres dilated and they were ready to be born at just  weeks.  “Scared, I called my partner, Chris Kerr, , and he came in within two hours. Trent came out at .pm weighing lb oz and Tallulah was born at .pm at only lb oz. “We are allowed to see the babies separately and I’ve been isolated. Me and Chris can only have contact from a distance as he’s isolated at home with my other two sons. “The staff are amazing and can’t do enough for me and my babies. I would love to give them my appreciation.

Ian Johnson, a cabin service director for the airline, passed away at St Thomas’ in London on Friday.Thought to be in his late s, he had been on a ventilator for  days and was receiving treatment in the hospital’s intensive care unit, the Sun reports.He is believed to be the first BA staff member to die from the flu-like virus, and had worked for the company for  years. title: chris packhams wildlife lockdown animal
story: NewsChris Packhams wildle lockdown: Animal magic with Britains springtime mammalsChris Packham continues his wildle lockdown series, with zoologist Megan McCubbin, and tells us about British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and MayShareCommentsByRhian Lubin:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsChris Packham tells us about mammals to watch out for in Spring " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWe might be in lockdown, but nature is doing the opposite at this time of year. Now is the time we can start to see mammals and their newborns pop their heads above ground. Today Chris Packham and zoologist Megan McCubbin talk about their favourite British mammals to keep your eyes peeled for in April and May. Badgers  Badgers are active throughout the course of the year and would’ve given birth in February or March, so in the next couple of weeks the young might be coming above ground for the first time. But they’ve very shy. They live in setts in the middle of the large territory that belongs to the whole family. The main sett is where the badgers live for most of the year and where they rear their babies but they also have smaller setts which they use in the Spring, Summer and Autumn so they can sleep near to where they find food.  A family of badgers can have a really big territory - each badger terrirtory might have up to six smaller setts. They’re sociable animals and like living with each other and love to play. And they’re really good at knowing which territory is theirs by their latrines - badgers have really distinct smelling faeces which they put at the edge of their territories so other families know they shouldn’t enter. It’s quite a sophisticated set up and is essential to their survival. Bats  We have  species of bat in the UK,  of which are known to be breeding here - that’s almost a quarter of our mammal species. They’re emerging this time of year and you can see them in all areas - urban or rural. But bats are always betteryou’ve got water near you. Soyou’re near a pond, reservoir, anything like that, you’ll see they’re beginning to emerge regularly. Bat populations have suffered severe declines during the past century. Deer  We had a muntjac deer near us the other day. You can tell the dference between male and female because the males have two very distinctive dark lines down the forehead and have very short antlers. The females are slightly paler. Muntjac have these amazing curved bottoms like rabbits. They are quite pig like with very sticky legs and are one of my favourites. They’re not native to the UK and were brought here in  to Woburn Safari Park. Some of them escaped, which is why they’re quite common across woodlands in the south of England. They’re very shy and secretive animals, soyou get a glimpse make the most of it. They’re fascinating, you can see them on roadsides nibbling at the verges. But they aren’t too popular with gardeners because they go for all the tasty parts of your plants - they love rosebuds. Also just be waryyou’re out walking your dog in an area where they might be and keep your animal on a lead. Foxes  April is the time we would expect start to see our fox cubs and they start to move around out of their den. If people are lucky enough to have a den in their garden shed, this is when they’ll first see the fox cubs. They’re very unfoxy when you first see them, they have quite blunt faces with short ears. They look quite cat-like, like kittens the nose hasn’t grown down yet and they’re chocolate brown in colour, they’re not red yet. Wobbling about with their skinny tails, they try to find their balance. We’ve already had reports of that cubs have been sighted as early as Christmas and January. This is really early, which is a sign of climate change. Fellow Springwatch presenter, Iolo Williams, told me he saw very young fox cubs and that was just before or after Christmas. That’s quite unusual. Otters  Pre s, where a lot of chemicals were put into our waterways, many of them were devoid of le and it damaged the eco systems. Everything at the top of the food chain disappeared. Otters only really occurred on the western side of the UK, in Wales, Cornwall and Devon. When I was a kid in the s, otters were a rather rare animal they were dficult to see and it didn’t occur in Hampshire where I grew up. Now they have recovered their range and have been found in every UK county, all the way across from the west and now including Kent. But they have not recovered their numbers, so there’s still scope for more otters to exist in our environment, particularly now our waterways have been cleaned up. We can’t be complacent about otter conservation just because they’re back everywhere - they’re not back in numbers they were, but it’s great to see them turning up. In urban areas they have even been turning up and you can see them in daytime from footpaths. Otters were almost an enigma and now are mostly accessible. The Sainsbury’s supermarket in Andover has a path that runs alongside the river and while you’re pushing your trolley you can look over the side and see them. How to make a hedgehog house and highway  Hedgehogs are a favourite this time of year - everyone loves hedgehogs. It’s mild and now’s the time they’re coming out into the garden soyou have a trap camera, now is the time to set it up. You can also make a little hedgehog house which is really simple. Get a bucket, put some hay or straw, grass, any long organic matter, inside the bucket, just something the hedgehog can hide in. Lie the bucket on its side and keep it steady with something so it doesn’t roll. Put it under a hedge or somewhere not exposed – they’re very secretive and shy things and are much more comfortable when they feel secure.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailShoppers waited as long as three hours in insane supermarket queues as Britons stocked up for Easter during the coronavirus lockdown. Long lines snaked through car parks on Good Friday as customers were forced to stay at least two metres apart and stores limited the number of people allowed inside due to social distancing rules. With many stores closed on Sunday, queues at some shops formed an hour before they opened and had hundreds of customers, and some shoppers said they gave up or didnapost bother at all because the wait was so long. Britons are facing an unprecedented Easter bank holiday weekend thanks to the Covid- pandemic and a lockdown that is now in its third week and set to be extended. Have you been affected by coronavirus  Email webnews@mirror. A Twitter user in West Sussex wrote: @Tesco Iaposve just been speaking to someone who has just finished a  hour sht on a Covid ward. She is in a -hour queue to get into your Crawley store. She is not allowed to jump the queue. How is that OK A Tesco worker replied: Although we ask our security to stick to the rules, we would also expect them to use common sense in times like these and let them through. I will contact the storeyou let me know which one it is. A man in Birmingham wrote: Queues at the supermarkets this weekend are giving me anxiety!  Looked like - hour+ queues at Asda and Sainsbury’s near me. Hope it’s just for Easter weekend and normal service resumes shortly. A woman in London wrote: Thank goodness I donapost need any more shopping now until next week.  Itaposs literally taken  hours to get a few essential bits in my local Sainsburyaposs and Waitrose. The last time I saw queues that long, I was outside Madame Tussauds during the school holidays. And another added: Waited in a queue at the butchers for way over an hour, all because I wanted lamb for Easter.A woman in Scotland tweeted: Well folk seem determined to aposovershotapos for Easter. The queue is all the way round our local Tesco’s very large car park #GoodsFriday. Photos posted on social media showed queues stretching well into car parks where barriers were set up to keep things orderly. In Cwmbran in South Wales, a man who posted a photo of shoppers waiting to enter an Aldi wrote: Queue for Aldi is insane mind.  Pictures showed shoppers queing in a car park outside an Asda in Brighton, East Sussex, long lines outside a Morrisons in Seaburn, South Tyneside, and similar scenes at a Sainsburyaposs store in Heaton, Newcastle. Shoppers told to expect long queues Families have been warned that queues to get into supermarkets might be even longer than usual on Saturday, as a result of Sunday trading laws. Shops in England and Wales - but not Scotland - have to shut their doors on Easter Sunday and Christmas daytheyaposre over  square metres in size.  And these rules apply coronavirus or not - meaning even more families than usual will need to stock up on essentials this Saturday. To make matters even worse, Friday and Monday count as Sundays thanks to their bank holiday status over Easter - meaning big shops are operating reduced hours on those days too. Throw coronavirus restrictions on the number of people allowed into shops at once and you have a recipe for the mother of all queues.  On a normal Sunday big shops can open for six hours, between am and pm. This weekend, those restrictions apply to Friday and Monday, while shops over a certain size must close entirely on Sunday. Then there are additional hours reductions as a result of coronavirus. Some shops are closing earlier so staff have more time to restock shelves. Police face criticism for patrolling supermarkets A police force is facing criticism after its officers patrolled a Tesco and found that the non-essential aisles were empty. Cambridgeshire Police officers visited the supermarket just a day after Northamptonshireaposs chief constable faced a backlash for suggesting officers could search shopping trolleyspeople kept flouting social distancing rules. Home Secretary Priti Patel hit back and said checking supermarket trolleys is not appropriate.

Aimée Goold from East Retford, Nottinghamshire shared the distressing image on Thursday yesterday after wearing personal protective equipment for over thirteen hours during her sht. Aimée, who works at Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospital, revealed she had been working  hour weeks and begged people to “remember her face” when thinking of going out this weekend. The photo shows an exhausted Aimée in her unorm with red welts and marks across her cheeks and nose. title: healthy nurses final words before
story: NewsHealthy nurses final words before being put on ventilator and dyingTough retired nurse Lynne Limbert was placed on a ventilator and knew it was coming. Her heartbroken son urged people to stay at home to protect the NHSShareCommentsByJonathan HumphriesJoseph WilkesReporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsGrandmother Lynne Limbert, pictured here with husband Paul, was killed by coronavirus at the age of  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA son was forced to say his last goodbye to his dying NHS nurse mum while wearing full protective gear as she who uttered the heartbreaking final words: Tell my husband I love him. Grandmother Lynne Limbert was killed by coronavirus at the age of  after beating bowel cancer just the previous year. Her son Phil Limbert said his mum was tough and it was asshe knew she was dying, reports the Liverpool Echo. Phil said: My mum and dad had a long standing joke between them. My mum would go to the caravan in Wales at weekends, she loved going to the caravan. She would say to my dad, aposright, see you laterapos. He would say aposI love youapos and she would roll her eyes and say aposdittoapos. He knew she loved him, it was just a bit of a joke. But in the hospital they had to put her on a ventilator and she needed sedating. Before they did, she got one of the staff and said apostell my husband I love himapos. Itaposs a bit like she knew. She was not soft my mum. Lynne, a retired nurse, from Broadgreen in Liverpool, had beaten bowel cancer last year and was healthy and active, spending her days doting on her two grandsons and enjoying a busy social le.  But after a few days of feeling under the weather, Lynne was rushed to hospital where her lungs were unable to recover and she died on Tuesday afternoon.Administrator Phil said he was forced to say goodbye to his unconscious mum, who he described as his hero, in full protective gear. Through tears, Phil said staff at the Royal Liverpool Hospital, where he also works, were absolutely amazing, holding her hand so she was not alone and making sure she did not feel any pain. Phil, , said: She was in hospital for a total of  nights. I saw her a few days before she went in and she was complaining that she was just a bit cold. She was just like aposclose the door, Iaposm a bit chillyapos, and it just sort of came on from there. We used to message quite a lot on Facebook, and over the next few days she was still upbeat but she was saying her head was pounding and she felt like she had been hit by a train. Phil says his mum seemed to improve and remained in good spirits. However around two weeks before her death her devoted husband, Philaposs dad Paul Limbert, rang the NHS  number for advice - and based on her symptoms an ambulance was immediately dispatched. Lynne was fully aware, but by that point was so breathless she could hardly string a sentence together and was kept in the back of the ambulance for around an hour while paramedics provided her with oxygen.  That was the last Philaposs dad saw of his we. Phil, his older brother Chris Limbert and their dad Paul were then faced with the tortuous experience of waiting to seeLynne would recover while not being able to visit due to strict infection controls at the Royal. Phil says the family were kept up to speed with regular phone calls from the hospital, but after  days he received the worst possible news - all treatment options had been exhausted. He said: Then it was like wow, this is so real. We had not been able to see her, we were not there to see how it was developing. You just donapost believe it.  Phil was allowed to pay a final visit to his mum with PPE protection, but his dadaposs health conditions meant he was too high risk and Chris could not face seeing his mum attached to tubes and wires. He said: I didnapost want to stay for the turning off of the machine, I didnapost want to remember her that way and I didnapost want to see her go, although they did give me that option and said you can take as long as you need. I got to say goodbye to her and hold her hand. I had messages from all the family saying how much they missed her and how much she was loved. I told her she was going to see my grandad and nan, and that she was not in pain anymore. Lynne had no health problems, said Phil, and she loved going for walks as part of a walking group, as well as enjoying a drink with her sister Christine who lived opposite. Phil said she was devoted to her grandchildren, his three-year-old son Oscar and Chrisaposs -year-old son Zak, and would do anything for anyone. Lynne spent her working le as a nurse in Broadgreen Hospital, before doing a short stint in the Royal and then moving on to Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. Although Phil has been able to see his dad since Lynneaposs death, they have observed social distancing so he has not even been able to hug him. He said: We observed social distancing rules but before this I was one of those people who would watch the news and think aposoh it will all blow over in a couple of weeksapos. You donapost think it will happen to you.

story: NewsInside UKs makesht coronavirus morgue branded the bleakest place in BritainHarrowing images have emerged of the makesht morgue which will be used at the NHS Nightingale Hospital in London for the coffins of coronavirus patients who do not make itShareCommentsByAnna MacSwan:,  APR NewsPhotos reveal the refrigerated morgue inside the new hospital" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Harrowing pictures have emerged of a makesht morgue for the bodies of coronavirus victims.Located at Londonaposs new NHS Nightingale Hospital, the images show refrigerated container units with row upon row of shelves. Trucks carrying coffins began arriving at the field hospital, which was set up at the ExCel conference centre in just nine days, on Wednesday. The Sun reports that the east London siteaposs ICC Capital Hall, located on the ground floor, has now been turned into a -hour mortuary for the bodies of Covid- patients who do not make it.The huge space - which usually costs £, a day to hire - is normally used for events such as award ceremonies and dinners.Follow the latest coronavirus updates hereBut now, a source at the facility describes it as the most bleak place in Britain. “Upstairs, doctors and nurses are working frantically around the clock saving lives. Down here in the dark gloom, there is just eerie quiet, they said. “This is the reality of what we are dealing with — row after row of bodies. The wider public needs to wake up to the brutal reality of what is going on. Coffins will be stacked inside the containers, which will be kept at a temperature below C, while funerals are arranged. The facility will be used for patients from both the NHS Nightingale and hospitals across the south east and trucks have been hired to bring up to  victims at a time. The Sun reported last month that the Government has also made arrangements for  mobile mortuaries with a combined capacity of , bodies to be deployed across the UK as the pandemic nears it peak. Another temporary morgue is being set up at Wanstead Flats in East London and will be the size of two football pitches.  The , bed NHS Nightingale hospital admitted its first patients earlier this week as it gears up to treat thousands who have fallen ill with the deadly bug. It was officially opened by the Prince of Wales last week, who said the pioneering facility offers us an intensely practical message of hope for those who will need it most at this time of national suffering. More than , members of staff will be needed to run the hospital when it reaches full capacity, which members of the army worked -hour days to finish as soon as possible.

Eric Roberts was visiting land near Aberffraw, Wales, and realised another vehicle was heading his way despite the lane to the beach at Porth Cwyfan, Anglesey  - despite it being closed The beauty spot is famous for its medieval church which sits on an island off the coast. Villager Eric Roberts, , explained he was checking on his sheep when he spotted a blue car parked on a hill above the beach this morning. He said: “There’s been a ‘Road Closed’ sign and cones on the lane for a few days now. The guy had obviously moved them to get to the beach.“I waited around a few minutes and watched as he loaded his kayak into the car. Then he came driving up the lane and had to move the sign and bollards again to continue his journey. “I decided to politely confront him and explain calmly why he shouldn’t have been there.” Eric filmed the stand-off in a video which has been shared almost , times and had , views on Facebook. The grey haired man - wearing shorts and sandals - is seen climbing out of his blue -plate Jaguar. Eric asks him to replace the cones and sign to prevent other accessing the beach, before telling him: “You shouldn’t be here in the first place.” The man replies: “The rules were set for big towns and cities. Here in the rural environment it’s a completely dferent kettle of fish. “I’ve done contamination control. I know what I’m talking about.” Eric tells him: “The government says essential travel only. With a kayak  Do you think that’s essential ” He replies: “No, but I am working away from other people.” The man says he lives in nearby Menai Bridge, where the tidal waters of the Menai Straits separate Anglesey from mainland Wales, and Eric asks why he hasn’t chosen to canoe closer to home. “What’s wrong with the Straits to go with that plastic thing you’ve got in the car  Nothing.” Eric says. “Why come here ” The man replies: “The current in the Straits is quite strong.”  Eric says: “Good - you’ll get a good paddle, it’ll give you good muscles.” The confrontation ends with the man ing to reassemble the roadblock. Eric said afterwards: “It’s a popular little spot in summer, we might see eight cars parked up at a time. “But there’s no reason to be down there now unless you live in the village. I couldn’t believe my ears when he tried to claim the rules only applied to towns and cities. They’re for everyone! “I was waiting for him to come back with a cocky reply, but he admitted himself that coming here with a kayak isn’t essential travel.

title: old peoples adorable coronavirus lifeline
story: NewsOld peoples adorable coronavirus leline keeping them connected in lockdownMusic for Dementia  is helping older people with dementia or Alzheimers stay connected to the music and people they love during the Covid- lockdownShareCommentsByJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  APR NewsOlder people can feel isolated as theyre separated from loved ones in lockdown " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCoronavirus has put the whole country in lockdown with people being told to stay in their homes to slow the spread of Covid-. Restaurants, pubs and theatres are now closed, along with schools, and people are being told to only leave their homes when they have to get essential supplies, like medicine and food, or for exercise daily. Group gatherings are now totally banned with people being told to stay six feet away from others at all times. The elderly, who are especially at risk to infection from coronavirus, are among the group of the most vulnerable who have been told they must self-isolate for  weeks in a bid to keep them safe. But this can be an incredibly lonely experience for OAPs, who are unable to spend time with their loved ones or socialise.And now  people living with dementia who are separated from their families in the Coronavirus lockdown have explained how music has become a leline in keeping them connected.Moyra Tourlamain, , lives at home with her husband John, , who was diagnosed with dementia in . They have had to stay away from family and friends but have found solace in online music sessions via the Music for Dementia  campaign. Moyra said: John and I have always been into music – in fact one of the reasons I married him was for his record collection! It’s played a big part in our le and still does. Before the Covid- pandemic they would attend music classes designed to help people with dementia in their local area near Cambridge. But although John has missed out on the face-to-face connection, his symptoms – which have been heightened recently due to the isolation – have been alleviated by attending online versions of the sessions. Former BBC bureaucrat Moyra said: As Hans Christian Andersen famously said, aposwhere words fail, music speaksapos. The online sessions have been a leline not just for John but for me. They are a landmark in what are very long weeks. I think it’s really important for our general wellbeing. It’s also a whole new experience and the engagement with the computer is important for John. It’s really good to see everybody, to connect and make the music together. There are hundreds of thousands of people who are in the same boat as us who might feel lonely and isolated and their conditions may have got worse as a result. We’d urge them to go onto the Music for Dementia  website and find out how to make the most of music during this time.  Music for Dementia  – a campaign backed by broadcaster Lauren Laverne to get more access to music for the , people living with dementia in the UK – has launched a new Musical Guide for those experiencing heightened anxiety during the lockdown. And more and more people are now using Music for Dementia ’s Musical Map, which gives information about online services for those with dementia, as well as taking advantage of Dementia Discos and live streamed events. It comes amid reports that UK care homes are in danger of being overwhelmed by the coronavirus with staff warning they are at “breaking point”. Lauren Laverne said: We’ve already seen how music has played a vital role in keeping people’s spirits up across the world during isolation. It echoes exactly what the Music for Dementia  campaign has been saying - although the feeling of isolation is an ongoing situation for people with this condition. For people living with dementia, music is a leline to connect in a way that nothing  can. Don Leitch, , of Royston, Hertfordshire, has been living with dementia for seven years and has been separated from his daughter, Caroline, due to the coronavirus. Caroline, , would see her dad at least once a week before the lockdown and pick him up from his home to accompany him to weekly music sessions run by a local group Together In Sound. She said: Music therapy is one of the very few positive things added to his le since being diagnosed with dementia. My dad has lost a lot but this one positive thing that has been added, and brought us closer together. In the car on the way there, I’ll play the music he likes listening to. He loves The Shadows. Caroline explained they are join each other and other people living with dementia for online sessions – which have been just as much of a relief to her as it has to her dad. Many music organisations have already made their services available digitally and these are being added to Music for Dementia ’s digital Musical Map, an advice hub of virtual events and activities that people living with dementia can participate in. Examples of online music events include The London Symphony Orchestra, now streaming online-concerts and The Sofa Singers, a new weekly online event which sees  people come together for a -minute rehearsal where they learn a classic song and sing it together. Music for Dementia  is urging music services that are moving online to get in touch, so they can be added to Musical Map.

It also warns that many of these workers are ineligible for Government wage subsidy schemes, and could be forced onto benefits unless a bigger safety net is created.Speaking to the Sun, the thinktankaposs head of economics Alfie Stirling said: “Despite the Government’s interventions to protect jobs and pay, millions could face the prospect of relying on benefits for the first time. “But Universal Credit payments are insufficient to meet basic living costs. Having made welcome moves to prevent job losses, government must now turn to strengthening the UK’s safety net as well. Follow the latest coronavirus updates here“If not, we risk consigning millions to the poverty trap through no fault of their own — a trap that many may struggle to break out of.” A new report by the NEF has identied four groups of workers who are at the highest risk of ending up jobless. They include those on fixed-term contracts, zero-hours contracts, part-time workers and the self-employed. Although Chancellor Rishi Sunik has announced a multibillion pound package of support for self-employed workers, which will pay a grant worth % of earnings, this money will not be available until June. It is feared that this will come too late for many smaller businesses and freelance workers. Of the .m employees at risk of ending up jobless, some .m work in industries that have been forced to close due to social distancing rules, such as restaurants and shops. The NEF has urged the Chancellor to guarantee a minimum income of £ for all working-age adults, rather than forcing millions to apply for Universal Credit. It comes as separate research has found that coronavirus has wiped out any hope of “levelling up” the UK, with the crisis set to hit the north hardest economically. Analysis from the Learning and Work Institute suggests that the gains of five years of jobs growth – during which employment increased to a record high – have been reversed in just one month. The thinktank’s report warns that despite the measures put in place by government to protect jobs, unemployment is set to rise further and faster than during any recession on record.

That#s their work, which they all take very seriously.“Just don’t heckle nobody paid money to listen to you and it irritates everyone including the artist who might cut short a performance.”The turn of the millennium would see the Caird play host to some comedians who are perhaps more famous for their withering put-downs and bilious invective towards those brave or stupid enough to disturb their flow.Comedy at the Caird: Special series looking back at the greatest comedians who#ve performed at Dundee#s Caird Hall" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp comedy-at-the-caird-special-series-looking-back-at-the-greatest-comedians-whove-performed-at-dundees-caird-hall embed # secretPKNwyclLJ" data-secret"PKNwyclLJ" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Comeback king Jimmy Carr, who gave his first of seven performances at the city centre venue in , has made a career out of his responses to unruly audience members.Roy “Chubby” Brown regularly dances out on stage as the crowd insult his portly proportions while the top hat-wearing scattergun Jerry Sadowitz prefers verbal evisceration.One comic, however, nipped any notion of heckling in the bud before he even starting his set at the Caird in .Susan added: “The audience did as they were told when Micky Flanagan appeared.“Micky came on stage and said ‘this is what’s going to happen, I will talk for an hour, you will listen then there will be an interval when you can go to the bar. I willto the stage and you will listen until I am finished.’“They did exactly as he said. No-one exited to go the toilet or asked for the bar during his performance.”The overwhelming majority of audience members at comedy shows are courteous and they have certainly been spoiled for choice at the Caird in the last  years.Home-grown favourite Frankie Boyle, Have I Got News for You star Paul Merton and Irish funnyman Dara O’Briain would be among the dozens to bring headline shows to the city centre in the st century.In , Sarah Millican made history, as she became the first female stand-up to headline a show at the Caird.That year would also mark a bittersweet moment for Susan as Billy Connolly gave his Dundee swansong.But as Susan recalls, the Big Yin managed to steal the show  hours before he was due to bow out.She added: “The night before his show, Jake Bugg was appearing and Billy came along with his daughter.“I got them discreetly seated in the balcony, got back downstairs and the fire alarm was activated. It was full evacuation.“By the time I got back to the balcony for Billy, the house lights were up full and instead of leaving the building the standing stalls audience were applauding Billy.“It was so lovely but we had to move quickly.”The following year would mark another milestone for comedy.Kevin Bridges would storm his way into Caird Hall folklore in  by selling out five shows in a row, a record run for the iconic venue.Almost  years have passed since Bob Hope first strode onto the Caird’s floorboards and set the standard for the stellar quality of comics to follow.The acts that have passed through the doors since would make up a hall of fame of stand-up comedy.A gut-busting night of hilarity seems a distant prospect in the midst of the current pandemic.Rest assured, the Caird Hall will be there to bring back the sounds of laughter. Hopefully, not just post-lockdown, but for  more years to come.

title: dundee fc dundee united title spfl vote
story: Dundee could decide Dundee United’s promotion fate after a day of chaos in Scottish football.Tele Sport understands the Dark Blues are the Championship side whose vote on the SPFL resolution to “call” the season has not yet been counted.As a result, with the plan having been passed by Premiership, League One and League Two Clubs, Dundee now hold the power to decide whether the League’s plan succeeds or fails.A vote in favour would see the season terminated in Scotland’s bottom three isions, prize money distributed, and Dundee United declared Championship title winners.A vote against will send the SPFL back to the drawing board.The Tangerines were tonight staying tight-lipped on the situation.However, their city rivals issued a y statement in which they notably failed to confirm which way they had voted –indeed they had at all – then called for an alternative approach.“As we all know, clubs are struggling at the moment,” read the Dark Blues’ communique.“The language in the currentproposal condemns clubs to be financially worse off than they already are as we sit here today. This has been dficult to accept.“The SPFL board and executive freely admit that they focused on the sporting merit of the proposal and did not take into consideration any financial fall out to their member clubs.“Fundamentally, we believe that in these exceptional and uncertain times, no member club should be worse off as a result of this proposal than they are today.“The current proposal will see member clubs cumulatively have in the region of £.-£ million pounds of lost revenue.“Amongst the member clubs there have been numerous discussions of the SPFL’s offer as well as viable, equitable proposed alternatives that could see, potentially, a neutral outcome for all clubs involvedthe season cannot be finished.“In all cases, current placement monies could be distributed to the member clubs in very short order while maintaining all SPFL obligations.“Make no mistake we would have to work quickly and diligently to ensure that members’ current needs are met and that the democratic process is followed, but it is achievable.”An SPFL spokesperson added: “It is very important that clubs consider carefully the resolution and we are grateful to those clubs who have voted already.“With the Ladbrokes Premiership and Ladbrokes Leagues One and Two isions each having approved the resolution, we await the voting slip from the one Ladbrokes Championship club that has yet to vote.“We will provide an update as soon as we are in a position to do so.”The SPFL set an initial deadline of pm for clubs to vote.However it is understood league rules give members  days to vote on resolutions – and Dundee are keen to weigh up their options.It is believed Partick Thistle and Inverness Caley Thistle were the two Championship sides to vote against the plan.As a result, Dundee appear to be in a position to set whichever agenda they please in negotiations with the SPFL.🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to title: dundee fc james mcpake craig levein dundee united
story: Dundee manager James McPake has revealed Craig Levein tried to take him to Dundee United.McPake – discussing his playing career on the Evening ’s Twa Teams, One Street podcast – says United were one of three top-flight teams in Scotland who wanted to sign him on a free transfer in  as he prepared to leave Livingston.But he opted for Coventry in the English Championship and has no regrets about the decision.The -year-old said: “I met Craig Levein, who at the time was the manager at Dundee United. I was free to talk to clubs.“I spoke to Mark McGhee at Motherwell and Gus MacPherson at St Mirren.“The chance to go to England and play for that club [Coventry] came up and it was a no-brainer really.“My agent and I sat down…we didn’t need to think about it.“There were other reasons why it was more beneficial for me – you’re trying to make a living in your career.“I had three top-flight teams up here who I had the chance to go to.“Lee Wilkie was at Dundee United at the time. I remember Craig saying that he would be one of the people I’d be coming in to try and play beside.“That was the three teams interested but thankfully I chose Coventry.“I really enjoyed the experience of playing and living in England. I was down there at .“I think I played my best football at Coventry.”The Dark Blues gaffer and Hearts legend Levein would cross paths again years later, this time with international football on the agenda.But for McPake and Scotland, it wasn’t meant to be and he ended up being capped by Northern Ireland and Michael O’Neill.He said: “I was at Coventry and Craig Levein was Scotland manager at the time.“Michael McBride, our physio, worked with me at Livingston and he was the national team physio.“He’d be telling me, ‘They’re down watching you’.“A few times I was really close. I was desperate to just get in and experience it.“But it got to the point that Michael O’Neill heard I could play with Northern Ireland [through a Coleraine-born grandparent].“He called Allan Preston [football agent] and Alan called me.“I said, ‘Can you ask Craig what the chances with Scotland would be ’ To be fair to Craig, he said, ‘I’d never say it’s a definite no buthe’s got the chance to play international football then I’d take it’.“Without saying ‘definitely no’, he definitely did say no!“I’ve still got mixed emotions about it. My dad wasn’t too sure, he didn’t want me to do it.“Other people advised me to do it and I had some great trips. I got one cap but I was in the squad seven or eight times.“Getting to train with people like Jonny Evans, Steven Davis…I loved the training and I loved the trips.“I would’ve liked to get more game time but it was causing a problem to my back and ultimately that’s why I stopped.”He made his Northern Ireland debut in a - hammering at the hands of the Netherlands on June , , just weeks after his Hibs side were beaten - by Hearts in the Scottish Cup Final.McPake – who came up against Dutch stars Arjen Robben, Wesley Sneijder and Robin van Persie – said: “It wasn’t like a normal friendly, it was mayhem.“The Amsterdam Arena was packed. I’m looking at it and going, ‘Wow’.“I think in that two weeks, with the Scottish Cup Final and then that game, I got beat - on aggregate.“I had a week in Dubai between that so I suppose that makes up for it.”McPake is approaching six years at Dens Park, after initially joining as a player in May , and he didn’t envisage such a long spell at the club.He said: “If I did, I’d be living in Dundee or somewhere around about there. I often say that to Dawn [we]. I love it up there.“In terms of players, Cammy [Kerr] was there – he was only a young boy. Gowser [Paul McGowan] signed at the same time as me.“It’s genuinely the best club I’ve worked with in terms of all the people there. It’s good going into work…when we’re doing okay!“It’s a friendly place and it’s a good club.”EXCLUSIVE: Lee Wilkie on starring alongside Claudio Caniggia at Dundee, Argentina star#s unusual pre-match ritual and representing Scotland" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-claudio-caniggia-dundee-fc-scotland embed # secretCakMIVhJs" data-secret"CakMIVhJs" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: dundee furlough coronavirus job retention scheme
story: Dundee are set to place football staff including management and coaches on furlough leave.The Dark Blues’ decision comes just over  hours after city rivals Dundee United confirmed measures to put its entire squad and several other employees on the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme.Managing director John Nelms tonight revealed the measures – that will see those affected receive full pay – taken by the Dens Park club, who sit third in the Championship.He said: “The UK Government and its agencies have also been extremely helpful in the offering of grants loans and providing relief through the Job Retention Scheme.“That includes HMRC. It is our experience, thus far, that this country’s handling of the crisis exceeds others in the mitigation of losses for businesses as well as iniduals.“In the coming days we will be implementing elements of the job retention scheme in respect of our staff and it is our intention that all are looked after fully throughout this crisis.“This includes our football players, football staff and administrative staff receiving full pay while they are on furlough for the foreseeable future.”Hello to all of the Dundee fans from all over the globe!  We hope this update finds everyone safe and well during these unprecedented and unimaginable times.  This, I have to say, is the strangest and scariest period, certainly of my letime and it has brought to the forefront, that, despite all of our dferences , we are truly all in this together and as such, we will get through this together.We at Dundee Football Club have been constantly monitoring the situation we find ourselves in due to the COVID- virus and have been taking advice, giving guidance, and implementing protocols to keep our staff, patrons and partners safe and sound as we ensure the sustainability of the club.First of all, the club do indeed have Business Interruption Insurance with specic additions of Notiable Diseases and Prevention of Access to our Commercial Combined Insurance Policy which should allow us to have options to reimburse those losses incurred due to the cancellation of matches. It would be our intention,the season is brought to an early conclusion, where practical, to reimburse those season ticket holders for the remainder of the season that was not played.  This will be further assessed for timelines, etc., as we make our way through the claims process. We have often said that the club is a family and that remains true throughout this situation.In addition to our insurance coverage, we have also sought to access ious sources of support offered by the League, the Association, Government agencies and our associates.  All that have been involved have been extremely helpful in our solidication of the club as a business.  I would like to personally thank John Bennett for his very generous and selfless gesture of suspending rent on the stadium. His call, on day one of this crisis helped to set the tone for all that followed throughout this shutdown and is the epitome of showing how we are all in this together.The UK Government and its agencies have also been extremely helpful in the offering of grants loans and providing relief through the Job Retention Scheme.  That includes HMRC. It is our experience, thus far, that this country’s handling of the crisis exceeds others in the mitigation of losses for businesses as well as iniduals.  In the coming days we will be implementing elements of the job retention scheme in respect of our staff and it is our intention that all are looked after fully throughout this crisis. This includes our football players, football staff and administrative staff receiving full pay while they are on furlough for the foreseeable future.We also think it is right to give credit to the dedicated workers at the SPFL and SFA. They have been working in an ever-changing landscape throughout this unprecedented event. They have continued to keep us informed and provide us advice on how to best navigate this predicament. They have freely shared the advice and guidance they are receiving from the government and UEFA as we all feel our way through these weeks. We continue to take advice and express our opinions on what football should look like when football resumes. Although none of us know yet what will transpire with this season, it is clear that football will be back.We’ve been inundated with requests on how people can help the club.  It’s truly been heart-warming. The one way to helpyou can – and onlyyou can # is to purchase season tickets and merchandise online.  We still have limited availability of this year’s Third Strip, which may become a collector’s item as it may never be worn.This supports the club as well as SSAFA and The Black Watch Association charities.  We will soon be launching our - kit in the upcoming days and we know it’s not enough to completely fill your appetite for football, but keep an eye on the social media sites for Dundee FC and DFC in the Community, which will provide some entertainment while we all do our part to save lives by staying home.We wish we had something more definitive to say, but we hope this brief update will provide some reassurance that we are still here and will remain here when this crisis is over. So from all of us at Dundee Football Club, please stay safe, keep your families safe, that is the most important thing and know that we are all in this together and we will come through this together!

title: dundee united mark connolly leadership coronavirus
story: Dundee United’s Mark Connolly has stressed the need for positivity in his leadership role during the lockdown.The -year-old Irish central defender is one of the senior players selected by manager Robbie Neilson to keep an eye on their team-mates while they are on furlough caused by the coronavirus.Along with the other United leaders – captain Mark Reynolds, Calum Butcher and Dillon Powers – Connolly will be keeping in touch with the people in his group to make sure they are staying well during Scottish football’s shutdown.Of course, mental health has as much value as physical well-being, especially in troubled times like these, and the former Kilmarnock player is keen to keep the mood upbeat.Connolly, whose is not receiving any contact or instruction from United during furlough, said: “We just need to keep ourselves as fit as we can so we are ready to go back when the professionals tell us when it is safe and well to do so.“We are due back in around the th of April because that is when the lockdown is due to end although we all know that could change.“It is frustrating because we don’t know what is happening and the club don’t know what is happening either.“However, we are a good group and we are all looking out for each other, which is huge.“Some boys will get through this no bother and there will be others who will find it harder and you just need to try and keep them positive.“We have the group chat and there is a lot of banter flying about to keep spirits up,” added Connolly.“One of the boys has put ‘week two in quarantine’ and posted this photo of a fish in a fishbowl!  It is all good craic.“A lot of the boys will be playing Call of Duty and FIFA and stuff and the older ones with the kids have dferent priorities.“I know it sounds clichéd but you have to stay positive and set yourself goals.“You can’t just wake up in the morning and lounge about on the couch and eat rubbish all day.“That is when it becomes dficultyou keep doing that and it turns into four or five weeks.“You see a lot more people out exercising now and maybe that is one of the positives that can come out of this terrible situation.“Hopefully, we can take the positives and it can change our lives for the better going forward.”United have chosen their group leaders wisely.All four – Connolly, Reynolds, Butcher and Powers – are confident, assured iniduals with a wealth of experience.Connolly is , Butcher and Powers are a year older, while captain Reynolds is . All command respect from their colleagues.Also, it is understood that a similar system has been put in place down through the younger ranks of the club, with leaders chosen from their own age group.Former Hearts and MK Dons boss Neilson saluted the efforts of the senior Tangerines quartet earlier this week.He said: “We have a good leadership group in terms of Mark Reynolds, Mark Connolly, Calum Butcher and Dillon Powers.“It is something we have always done but something we have stepped up because the club and I can’t communicate with the players because of the furlough.“We have good characters who speak to the rest of the players and make sure they are OK.“The players all speak to one another every other day. They also play these dferent computer games they play.“Now we have senior players who are in the leadership groups and they all have a certain number of boys to look after and stay in touch with.“All the boys stay in Dundee and are all a tight group.“They are in contact a few times a week, evenit is for a quick chat or catch-up.”Dundee United boss Robbie Neilson says uncertainty of having nodate is proving to be massive managerial challenge" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-robbie-neilson-coronavirus-spfl- embed # secretGkHvBVtO" data-secret"GkHvBVtO" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"🔵 In these troubled times, when many people are struggling to get out for their paper, we are pledging to help readers by providing a FREE digital edition of the Eveningfor three months. title: i cant thank you enough woman living with leukaemia praises tele for getting her meds delivered
story: A Dundee woman with leukaemia who was running out of medication during Covid- lockdown has praised the Tele for coming to her aid.June Brady, who was diagnosed with leukaemia three years ago, said she faced a #le or death situation# being stuck in her Ardler home.The government has ordered those living with serious underlying health conditions to self-isolate for a period of at least  weeks during the coronavirus epidemicThis meant the -year-old was unable to visit her local pharmacy on Macalpine Road to collect her monthly prescription which she relies on to relieve the side-effects of her cancer.June had attempted to contact the pharmacy to arrange for the prescription to be delivered.But despite phoning the store #hundreds# of times since Friday, she was unable to get through.Mum recovering from pneumonia claimed Angus Council initially refused to fix gas because they believed she had coronavirus" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp mum-recovering-from-pneumonia-claimed-angus-council-initially-refused-to-fix-gas-because-they-believed-she-had-coronavirus embed # secretVrLUeflQd" data-secret"VrLUeflQd" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"#I can’t get out and order my prescriptions like Oramorph and MST tablets among a lot of others,# the former nurse explained.#I seriously need my prescriptions to be delivered as I can’t do without my morphine tablets.#I have been ringing the chemist since Friday and can’t get through to them. I#ve run out of my tablets for next week so really worried now.#The Adler resident has been left fearing the worst, believing she could be facing serious health repercussionsshe was unable to get a hold of medication before her supplies ran out. vw, px"  June said: #I have a lodger who lives with me but he is  years old. He also has asthma and epilepsy so he can#t get out to collect it either.#I used to get it delivered before they started charging for £ for delivery but now I just go up to the shop and collect it myself.#I truly think this is a le or death situation that I am facing right nowI don#t get them.#But when Tele stepped in to enquire why June had been unable to arrange for her prescription to be delivered to her doorstep, Boot#s head office was able to find a solution.#The pharmacy have now contacted me and told me they will deliver the prescription on Thursday,# June said.#They said they will deliver it free of charge and will continue to do so for the duration of the coronavirus outbreak. I hope that they are able to do this for other people in my situation, some of whom might be a lot older than me.#I am just so relieved that it#s sorted and I can#t thank you enough for helping me out.#A spokesman for Boots said: #I was sorry to hear that she has been unable to get through to our Dundee Macalpine Road store and we are grateful to you for bringing this to our attention.#I have managed to get through to the store and they have received a new prescription from the GP today and are contacting June to update her what is happening.#They will need to order some items in for tomorrow and should be in a position to dispense the prescription tomorrow. I hope this will help to ease June’s worries.#

title: lee wilkie dundee fc dundee united out of contract
story: I have to say I feel for players at Dundee and United right now – especially those out of contract this summer.It’s a horrible situation for a lot of people in their jobs right now with no real knowledge of what is going to happen and footballers are no dferent.It is a job at the end of the day, a good one and one a lot of people would love to have.But, just like everyone , players have families and bills to pay. That goes for the clubs, too.That’s why I’m not surprised both the Dark Blues and the Tangerines have opted to use the government’s furlough scheme – they are businesses and they have to do what is right to ensure they stay afloat during this time when there’s no income.Like a lot of people in the city right now, that will bring a whole lot of worry to workers for what the future holds post-coronavirus.Not knowing where the next wage is coming from is a dreadful situation to be in.There are players at both clubs whose contracts end in a couple of months and they have my every sympathy.I’ve been through similar in my playing career and that uncertainty is probably the worst feeling you can have as a professional.Going through administration at Dundee was a dferent sort of situation but I ended up coming out of it with that question of how I was going to pay my bills.Back then I was prepared to take a wage cut to help the club but it was decided that wouldn’t be enough and I left Dens Park.EXCLUSIVE: Lee Wilkie on starring alongside Claudio Caniggia at Dundee, Argentina star#s unusual pre-match ritual and representing Scotland" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-claudio-caniggia-dundee-fc-scotland embed # secretVsZdl" data-secret"VsZdl" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"On top of everything, I had just finished rehab on my knee and wasn’t even sure I’d be able to play on anyway.Thankfully, Dundee United gave me a chance, though the uncertainty continued even so.I wasn’t sure my knee would hold up and they gave me a contract from September to June on £ per week – a far cry from the million-pound lestyle people associate with some footballers.There was an appearance fee on top but spending time on loan at Ross County meant I couldn’t get that and it was a really tough time in my career.Right now, there are worse things going on in the world with people’s health but adding the stress and worry of work problems just piles on top for a lot of people.I think the move to furlough staff for the time being is a sensible one for both city clubs.What the players are desperate for now is some sort of certainty from the powers-that-be.The UK Government has gone to town on footballers this week completely unfairly.They are an easy target right now.I understand why people think players should front up and take pay cuts to either help non-playing staff at clubs or the NHS or whatever.However, they all seem to be lumped in the same bracket when only a small percentage of professional footballers earn millions of pounds.Boys playing for clubs like Dundee or United or St Mirren, Hamilton etc are not earning fortunes and they have bills to pay like everybody .I think everyone should be doing their bit to help during the coronavirus pandemic, whether that’s through paying taxes or some sort of voluntary work, but it seems like footballers have been called out because they are an easy target.There are plenty of people across the country earning big bucks but not getting hammered.A better way to go about it would have been to say to players exactly what their club needs to save and to give an option to donate part of their salary to the NHS.It seems a weekly occurrence at the moment that we see an SPFL meeting as the time decisions will finally be made.I’m not holding my breath too much for this one tomorrow but you never know.I saw Celtic put out they want to finish the season but they are in a position where they can take the high ground.Everyone has their own agenda but what we really need, what clubs and players need, is some idea of how Scottish football will continue.Cheering on the Virtual Grand National over the weekend was about as close to sporting excitement
